user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of calc_userdigest:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
calc_userdigest (struct DigestAlgorithm *da,
                 const char *username, const size_t username_len,
                 const char *realm, const size_t realm_len,
                 const char *password,
                 uint8_t *ha1_bin)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->hashing);
  digest_update (da, username, username_len);
  digest_update_with_colon (da);
  digest_update (da, realm, realm_len);
  digest_update_with_colon (da);
  digest_update_str (da, password);
  digest_calc_hash (da, ha1_bin);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Indirect recursion can only occur via function calls. The only statements in this function that invoke other routines are the call expressions listed above, so each of those call sites must be inspected to determine whether they call (directly or indirectly) calc_userdigest. Other parts of the code (function signature, parameter declarations, braces, and non-call expressions) cannot introduce a call path back to calc_userdigest and therefore do not need to be investigated. Note that there is no explicit self-call to calc_userdigest in the function body; all potential recursion sources are the listed calls (including the two repeated calls to digest_update_with_colon and digest_update).
